pdhp1:0.2: Hail and Homage to all Buddhas, Dharmas and the Noble Saṅghas.
pdhp1:1: Mind precedes thoughts, mind is their chief, they are impelled by mind,
pdhp1:2: if with a base mind one speaks or acts,
pdhp1:3: through that, suffering follows him like a wheel follows the ox’s foot.
pdhp2:1: Mind precedes thoughts, mind is their chief, they are impelled by mind,
pdhp2:2: if with pure mind one speaks or acts,
pdhp2:3: through that, happiness follows him like a shadow which does not depart.
pdhp3:1: Here he laments, after death he laments, the wicked one laments in both places,
pdhp3:2: he laments, he suffers vexation, seeing the defilement of his own deeds.
pdhp4:1: Here he is happy, after death he is happy, the meritorious one is happy in both places,
pdhp4:2: he is happy… seeing the purity of his own deeds.
pdhp5:1: “He abused me, he struck at me, he overcame me, he robbed me,”
pdhp5:2: those who bear these ill-will their hatred is never appeased.
pdhp6:1: “He abused me, he struck at me, he overcame me, he robbed me,”
pdhp6:2: those who do not bear these ill-will their hatred is appeased.
pdhp7:1: Living contemplating what is pleasant, uncontrolled in sense faculties,
pdhp7:2: not knowing the limit in food, indolent, low in energy—
pdhp7:3: Māra surely overthrows that one, like wind overthrows a weak tree.
pdhp8:1: Living contemplating the unpleasant, well-controlled in sense faculties,
pdhp8:2: and knowing the limit in food, faithful, with energy aroused—
pdhp8:3: Māra does not overthrow that one, just as wind does not overthrow a mountain made of rock.
pdhp9:1: If you should find a prudent, wise companion, one who lives well, a wise one,
pdhp9:2: overcoming all your troubles you should live with that one, glad and mindful.
pdhp10:1: If you do not find a prudent, wise companion, one who lives well, a wise one,
pdhp10:2: like a king who abandons his conquered kingdom, one should live alone like a solitary elephant in the forest.
pdhp11:1: It is better to live alone, there can be no companionship with a fool,
pdhp11:2: one should live alone and not do anything bad, unconcerned like a solitary elephant in the forest.
pdhp12:1: He who, through desire, hatred, fear or delusion, transgresses Dhamma,
pdhp12:2: his fame diminishes, like the moon in the dark fortnight.
pdhp13:1: He who, through desire, hatred, fear or delusion, does not transgress Dhamma,
pdhp13:2: his fame increases, like the moon in the bright fortnight.
